conclusion: The problem involves finding the effective value of the induced EMF in a rotating square metal coil in a magnetic field.
When a coil rotates in a magnetic field, it generates an alternating current (AC) and the EMF is sinusoidal.
The coil is not rotating about its center but around an axis offset from the center.
The coil has side length L, N turns, and rotates at angular velocity ω around an axis OO' perpendicular to the magnetic field B, at a distance L/4 from side ab.
The axis is not at the center of the coil but offset by L/4.
Side ab is closer to the axis than side cd, with distances L/4 and 3L/4 respectively.
The EMF is proportional to the rate of change of the magnetic flux through the coil.
Magnetic flux φ is given by B × A × cosθ, where A is the area of the coil and θ is the angle between the area vector and the magnetic field.
The angle θ varies with time as θ = ωt due to the coil's rotation.
The instantaneous EMF is given by ε = N B A ω sin(ωt).
The coil is treated as rotating about its own axis, but it's actually rotating about an external axis offset from the center.
The area A used might not be equally effective in producing flux changes due to the offset axis.
Consideration of the moment of inertia or rotation path might be needed due to the offset axis.
The center of the coil is at a distance of 3L/4 from the axis of rotation.
